headline: Rep. Moran Introduces Building Youth Workforce Skills Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Nathaniel Moran, R-TX, has introduced the Building Youth Workforce Skills Act, aimed at enhancing job training opportunities for youth aged 16 to 21. The bill seeks to amend the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to allow the use of individual training accounts for eligible in-school and out-of-school youths.

The initiative responds to the growing need for effective workforce development strategies, particularly in the wake of economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. Many young individuals are facing barriers to accessing job training and skill development. By facilitating the use of individual training accounts, the proposed bill aims to provide financial flexibility, enabling youths to select customized training programs with qualified providers.

The potential impact of this legislation is significant, as it endeavors to empower young people by equipping them with relevant skills that meet the demands of a rapidly evolving job market. This could lead to increased employability and career advancement opportunities, ultimately fostering stronger economic growth in communities across the country.

Historically, workforce training programs have been underutilized by youths, with many lacking awareness of available resources. By establishing individual training accounts, the Building Youth Workforce Skills Act would not only streamline access to training but also promote better engagement from young participants. It aligns with broader workforce development goals by ensuring that youth are adequately prepared to join a workforce increasingly reliant on specialized skills and certifications.

The House Committee on Education and Workforce is set to review the bill, with advocates pushing for swift action to implement the reforms. As the job landscape continues to evolve, ensuring that the next generation possesses the necessary skills is more critical than ever.

headline: Rep. Morelle Introduces SCREENS for Cancer Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Joseph Morelle, D-NY, has introduced the SCREENS for Cancer Act aimed at reauthorizing and enhancing the National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program (NBCCEDP) for the years 2026 to 2030. The proposed legislation seeks to ensure vital screening and diagnostic services are accessible to low-income, uninsured, or underinsured women across the United States.

The SCREENS for Cancer Act comes in response to alarming statistics that project over 319,750 new cases of invasive breast cancer and nearly 43,000 related deaths in 2025. In addition, 13,360 new cases of invasive cervical cancer and 4,320 deaths from cervical cancer are anticipated. Founded in 1991, the NBCCEDP has played a critical role in providing lifesaving cancer screenings to underserved communities, reaching over 6.4 million individuals and facilitating more than 16.5 million screening exams. 

This legislation proposes significant program expansions and updates to address barriers that vulnerable populations face when seeking care. By implementing evidence-based strategies to improve outreach, the program aims to enhance cancer screening rates, specifically focusing on women who are geographically or culturally isolated. The revisions include augmenting follow-up services, improving access to screenings, and reducing disparities in cancer outcomes. 

The bill emphasizes the importance of early detection, with rescreening expected to lead to more cancers being identified at earlier, more treatable stages. By reauthorizing the NBCCEDP, the SCREENS for Cancer Act aims to prolong lives and advance health equity, ensuring all women have equal access to necessary services. The legislation has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for consideration.

headline: Rep. Murphy Introduces First Responders Retirement Parity Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Gregory F. Murphy, R-NC, has introduced the First Responders Retirement Parity Act, a legislative proposal aimed at amending the Internal Revenue Code to extend pension plan eligibility to certain firefighters, emergency medical technicians, and paramedics. This initiative is designed to ensure that these essential workers receive the same retirement benefits as their counterparts in other public safety roles.

The First Responders Retirement Parity Act responds to a noticeable disparity faced by emergency responders who have been excluded from certain governmental pension plans. By broadening the definition of governmental plan, the bill seeks to include public safety agency employees whose primary duties involve providing emergency response services. This change is anticipated to enhance the retirement security of these workers, acknowledging their critical contributions to public safety.

The context for this legislation stems from the increasing recognition of the demanding and often dangerous work performed by first responders. Many have expressed concerns over the adequacy of benefits currently provided, which can fail to meet the long-term needs of those who dedicate their lives to protecting communities. By expanding access to pension plans, the bill aims to align retirement benefits with the nature of the job.

If enacted, the First Responders Retirement Parity Act could significantly impact the lives of thousands of current and retired first responders, providing them with crucial financial support as they transition out of active service. The bill has been referred to the House Committees on Education and Workforce and Ways and Means for further consideration. This legislative move comes amidst wider discussions about the need to reinforce and support those in public service, particularly as the nation navigates ongoing challenges in emergency response and disaster management.

headline: Rep. Neguse Introduces Protecting Kids from Fentanyl Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Joe Neguse, D-CO, has introduced the Protecting Kids from Fentanyl Act, a critical piece of legislation aimed at combating the opioid crisis among school-aged children. This bill seeks to amend the Public Health Service Act by allowing the use of Preventive Health and Health Services Block Grants for purchasing life-saving opioid antagonists, such as naloxone, for schools. It also mandates the provision of training for staff on administering these medications and raising fentanyl awareness among students.

The introduction of this bill comes in response to a nationwide surge in opioid-related overdoses, especially among teens. As fentanyl has proliferated, schools have found themselves unprepared to address potential drug-related emergencies. By equipping schools with opioid antagonists and providing education, the legislation aims to save lives and foster a safer environment for students.

The potential impact of the Protecting Kids from Fentanyl Act is significant. With increased access to naloxone in schools, trained personnel will be ready to respond swiftly to overdose incidents. Additionally, integrating fentanyl awareness into school curricula will educate students about the dangers of drug use. This proactive approach could dramatically decrease the number of opioid-related fatalities in educational settings to protect the most vulnerable populations.

The bill addresses a pressing health crisis and represents a collaborative effort among lawmakers to tackle drug addiction and its consequences in communities. As it moves to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for review, supporters are optimistic about its chances of passage, especially amid growing public concern over the opioid epidemic's effects on youth.

The bill (H.R. 2383) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. McDowell, Addison [R-NC-6]...03/26/2025; Rep. Panetta, Jimmy [D-CA-19]...04/02/2025; Rep. Davis, Donald G. [D-NC-1]...04/09/2025.

headline: Rep. Obernolte Introduces CREATE AI Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Jay Obernolte, R-CA, has introduced the Creating Resources for Every American To Experiment with Artificial Intelligence Act of 2025, which aims to establish a National Artificial Intelligence Research Resource (NAIRR). This legislation seeks to enhance accessibility to AI research and development resources, enabling a broader range of individuals and institutions to contribute to the field.

The CREATE AI Act responds to growing concerns regarding the concentration of AI resources among large technology firms, which limits the diversity of perspectives in AI development. By democratizing access to computational resources and datasets, the bill is designed to foster innovation in AI and ensure that its benefits are widely distributed across the U.S. population.

A key highlight of the proposed legislation is the establishment of governance structures within the NAIRR that will facilitate collaboration among various government agencies, private sector organizations, and academia. The American research community will be empowered to engage in AI research under more equitable conditions, which is crucial for maintaining the U.S.'s leadership in this rapidly evolving field.

The bill underscores the importance of inclusivity by specifically targeting support for underrepresented groups in STEM fields. By providing necessary resources, including cloud computing and curated datasets, this initiative aims to stimulate participation among a more diverse set of researchers and students.

As AI technology continues to shape multiple facets of society, the CREATE AI Act represents a strategic effort to create a more inclusive innovation ecosystem. The proposed resource center will not only remove barriers to entry in AI research but also bridge the gap between advanced technology and community needs, ultimately enhancing the collective intelligence and ethical grounding of AI developments in the country. As it moves to committee, the bill reflects a proactive approach to addressing both opportunities and challenges in the AI landscape.

headline: Rep. Ogles Introduces Make Education Great Again Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Andrew Ogles, R-TN, has introduced the Make Education Great Again Act, aimed at improving educational outcomes by empowering parents, states, and local communities. The bill seeks to reduce federal oversight in education, giving more control back to families and local authorities.

The introduction of this legislation comes in response to growing concerns over federal mandates that critics argue have hindered parental choice and local governance in education. Ogles asserts that the current federal approach has led to a decrease in educational quality and accountability, emphasizing the need for reforms that allow parents to make decisions regarding their children's education. 

The proposed act emphasizes parental rights and seeks to ameliorate the relationship between federal and local education systems. It includes provisions for the Secretary of Education to ensure federal funds support local initiatives rather than bureaucratic regulations. The bill also proposes to promote school choice options, such as educational savings accounts and charter schools, and aims to reduce administrative burdens on state educational systems.

Moreover, this legislation is seen as a pivotal step towards restoring educational decision-making at the community level. By attempting to dismantle what proponents view as excessive federal control, the bill has generated significant interest across the political spectrum. Advocates believe that allowing local authorities to craft their educational policies will foster innovation and improve academic results.

In addition to placing a stronger emphasis on parental authority, the bill's framework sets out guidelines for spending within education programs without mandating new federal expenditures. As the bill moves to the Committee on Education and Workforce, its success may hinge on bipartisan support amid ongoing debates about educational governance in America.

The bill (H.R. 2386) was introduced on 03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Onder Introduces No Harm Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Robert Onder, R-MO, has introduced the No Harm Act in the House of Representatives, aiming to prohibit federal funding for sex-trait altering treatments for minors. The bill is designed to restrict the allocation of funds for medical procedures that seek to alter a minor's biological sex characteristics and aims to ensure that parents retain ultimate authority over health decisions for their children.

The introduction of the No Harm Act comes amid a growing national debate over gender identity and medical treatments for youth. Proponents of the bill argue that minors may not be fully equipped to make such significant decisions regarding their health, particularly when it comes to irreversible treatments. The bill outlines specific prohibitions on federal funding that would support sex-trait altering treatments and includes provisions allowing parents to decline such treatments for their children.

This legislative effort could have substantial implications, impacting medical institutions, including hospitals and clinics, that currently provide such treatments. By cutting off federal funds to entities offering these services, the bill aims to create a disincentive for medical professionals to administer procedures that alter a child's sex traits.

Additionally, the proposed legislation empowers parents with the right to make healthcare choices for their underage children and mandates that parental consent is obtained before any sex-trait altering procedure can be administered. The bill also stresses the importance of informed consent, requiring healthcare providers to give parents detailed information regarding potential risks associated with treatments.

As the No Harm Act moves through the legislative process, it highlights the contentious atmosphere surrounding healthcare regulations for minors, with advocates on both sides eager to see its impact on medical practices and parental rights across the nation.

The bill (H.R. 2387) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 4 co-sponsors: Rep. Harris, Andy [R-MD-1]...03/26/2025; Rep. Miller, Mary E. [R-IL-15]...03/26/2025; Rep. Biggs, Sheri [R-SC-3]...03/26/2025; Rep. Messmer, Mark [R-IN-8]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Smith Introduces Clean Energy Advancement Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Jane Smith, D-CA, has introduced the Clean Energy Advancement Act, aiming to enhance investments in renewable energy sources and accelerate the transition to a greener economy. This legislation proposes substantial tax incentives for businesses and homeowners who adopt solar, wind, and other renewable technologies, with a focus on reducing carbon emissions and promoting energy independence.

The introduction of this bill comes amid a rising national concern about climate change and the increasing costs of fossil fuels. In recent years, California has experienced significant climate-related challenges, including wildfires and droughts, prompting lawmakers to seek proactive solutions. By incentivizing the use of clean energy, Rep. Smith aims to alleviate the economic burden associated with climate-related disasters while contributing to job creation in the renewable energy sector.

The Clean Energy Advancement Act could have a transformative impact on both local economies and national energy policy. By encouraging investment in clean technologies, the bill not only aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but also serves to empower communities to become self-sufficient in energy production. The expected outcome is a dual benefit: enhanced environmental stewardship and a boost to local job markets focused on sustainable practices.

Historically, legislation promoting renewable energy has gained bipartisan support, especially as the impacts of climate change become increasingly evident. This bill builds on previous efforts while incorporating lessons learned from past initiatives. Should it be passed, the Clean Energy Advancement Act could pave the way for future investments and innovations, sealing California's reputation as a leader in the clean energy transition.

Overall, Rep. Smith’s initiative represents a crucial step toward a sustainable future, aligning economic growth with environmental responsibility.

The bill (H.R. 2388) was introduced on 03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Randall Introduces Quinault Indian Nation Land Transfer Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Emily Randall, D-WA, has introduced the Quinault Indian Nation Land Transfer Act, aimed at placing approximately 72 acres of land in Washington State into trust for the Quinault Indian Nation. This legislation seeks to enhance the tribe’s land base amid ongoing efforts to affirm their rights and sovereignty.

The bill serves as a response to the Quinault Indian Nation’s long-standing request for additional land to be recognized as part of their reservation. Recognizing and transferring the land into trust status aims to improve the tribe's ability to manage natural resources, develop infrastructure, and create economic opportunities without the constraints typically imposed by state laws. It will be administered by the Department of the Interior, ensuring adherence to federal regulations governing trust lands for recognized Indian tribes.

This initiative comes at a time when many Indigenous communities are advocating for greater autonomy and access to land—critical elements needed for cultural preservation and economic sustainability. By taking this step, the Quinault Indian Nation stands to strengthen its community and expand its capabilities in resource management.

The bill explicitly prohibits the land from being used for gaming purposes, emphasizing its intended use for residential, cultural, and environmental benefits rather than as a source of casino revenue. Furthermore, it ensures that existing treaty rights remain untouched, highlighting a commitment to maintaining the tribe's historical legal agreements with the federal government.

Randall's introduction of this bill illustrates a significant progression in Native American rights and land trust issues, which have been at the forefront of legislative discussions aimed at rectifying historical injustices against Indigenous peoples. The proposed law awaits further deliberation in the House Committee on Natural Resources, where it will undergo review and potentially advance toward enactment.

The bill (H.R. 2389) was introduced on 03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Ryan Introduces Strengthening Supply Chains Through Truck Driver Incentives Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Patrick Ryan, D-NY, has introduced the Strengthening Supply Chains Through Truck Driver Incentives Act of 2025, aimed at bolstering the trucking industry by offering a refundable tax credit to commercial truck drivers. This legislation responds to an ongoing shortage of drivers, aiming to attract new talent while supporting existing truck operators amid rising operational costs.

The bill proposes a $7,500 tax credit for qualified truck drivers, with enhanced benefits for new entrants into the profession. To qualify, individuals must hold a valid Class A commercial driver’s license and meet specified income thresholds. They must also demonstrate a commitment of at least 1,900 hours driving in a tax year, or meet modified criteria if new to trucking. By providing financial incentives, the legislation seeks to alleviate barriers for eligible applicants, including those completing apprenticeship programs.

Recent supply chain disruptions have highlighted the pivotal role of trucking in maintaining the flow of goods, with many companies facing delays due to the lack of qualified drivers. According to industry reports, the trucking sector is experiencing an estimated shortfall of up to 80,000 drivers. This shortage is contributing to increased shipping costs and longer delivery times, affecting consumers and businesses alike. 

By incentivizing careers in trucking, Rep. Ryan's bill could stabilize supply chains, ensuring that goods reach markets efficiently. The narrative surrounding the workforce challenge in logistics underscores the need for innovative policy solutions aimed at fostering a robust labor force capable of meeting the demands of a dynamic economy. The proposal is currently awaiting review by the House Committee on Ways and Means.

The bill (H.R. 2391) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Nunn, Zachary [R-IA-3]...03/26/2025; Rep. Amodei, Mark E. [R-NV-2]...03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Clyde Introduces SHORT Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Andrew Clyde, R-GA, has introduced the Stop Harassing Owners of Rifles Today Act, commonly referred to as the SHORT Act. This legislation aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code to redefine firearms, specifically removing short-barreled rifles and shotguns from the National Firearms Act's classification of regulated firearms. 

The introduction of the SHORT Act comes amid ongoing debates surrounding gun ownership rights and regulations in the U.S. Supporters argue that the bill seeks to alleviate unnecessary burdens on lawful gun owners, particularly those who possess short-barreled weapons for sporting and personal defense. Currently, these firearms require specific taxes and registration processes under the National Firearms Act, which many believe are overly stringent.

By altering the classification, the bill suggests that individuals who acquire or possess short-barreled rifles and shotguns would no longer face federal registration or licensing burdens, significantly simplifying ownership. This move could potentially lead to increased sales in the firearms market and greater accessibility for recreational weapon enthusiasts.

The SHORT Act also proposes to preempt certain state regulations and taxes on short-barreled firearms, further emphasizing individual ownership rights over state-imposed restrictions. This presents a contentious issue, particularly in states with stringent gun control laws, as it may conflict with local regulations designed to manage weapon ownership effectively.

Clyde's bill reflects a broader trend among certain lawmakers advocating for reduced firearm regulations, framing the conversation around personal freedom and constitutionally-protected rights. As the bill moves to the House Ways and Means and Judiciary Committees for further consideration, its potential impacts on both local and federal firearm regulations remain to be seen, highlighting a continuing divide in American gun policy discourse.

headline: Rep. Vasquez Introduces Honor Farmer Contracts Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Gabe Vasquez, D-NM, has introduced the Honor Farmer Contracts Act, aiming to unfreeze funding for agricultural contracts and prevent the closure of critical resources for farmers. This legislation addresses issues arising from funding disruptions at the Department of Agriculture, ensuring that all agreements made prior to the bill's enactment are honored, and that farmers receive payments they are owed.

The Honor Farmer Contracts Act was introduced in response to growing concerns within the agriculture community about financial instability due to stalled funding. The repercussions of these disruptions have left many farmers and agricultural entities vulnerable. With essential services and resources at risk of being diminished, this legislation seeks to safeguard the interests of those in agricultural sectors by mandating the immediate release of funds and the adherence to existing contracts.

Further, the bill stipulates that the Department of Agriculture cannot cancel any signed agreements with farmers unless the terms have not been met. This measure aims to provide farmers with greater security, allowing them to plan and operate without the fear of losing vital support. Additionally, the legislation prohibits the closure of local Farm Service Agency and Natural Resources Conservation Service offices unless Congress is given proper notice and justification at least 60 days in advance.

As the agricultural sector faces challenges from various fronts, including climate change and economic pressures, the Honor Farmer Contracts Act represents a proactive approach to ensuring that farmers are supported and can continue to contribute to the nation’s food security. The bill has garnered attention from farming advocates who view it as a crucial step in stabilizing the agricultural industry amidst uncertain times.

headline: Rep. Smith Introduces Rural Veterinary Workforce Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Adrian Smith, R-NE, has introduced the Rural Veterinary Workforce Act, aiming to enhance access to veterinary services, particularly in rural areas, by exempting certain loan repayment assistance from taxable income. This proposed legislation, introduced on March 27, 2025, seeks to address the ongoing shortage of veterinarians serving rural communities, a gap that has been increasingly recognized as a significant barrier to livestock health and animal care.

The Rural Veterinary Workforce Act proposes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code, specifically providing tax relief for those participating in state loan repayment or forgiveness programs aimed at increasing veterinary service availability in underserved regions. This initiative reflects concerns about the aging veterinary workforce and the challenges young graduates face when considering rural practice due to high educational debt.

The bill is expected to have a substantial impact on recruitment and retention of veterinarians in rural areas, which often struggle to attract qualified professionals. By alleviating the financial burden from loans, the act plans to incentivize more graduates to consider careers in these critical, yet underserved, markets. 

As the number of practicing veterinarians continues to dwindle, especially in regions with a high agricultural focus, the legislation has drawn bipartisan support with co-sponsors from both sides of the aisle, highlighting the collective recognition of this pressing issue. Through this legislative effort, Rep. Smith aims not only to bolster the veterinary workforce in rural settings but also to ensure the sustainability of animal health services essential for rural economies. 

With the bill currently referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means, stakeholders await discussions on its potential to foster a healthier, more viable rural veterinary landscape.

headline: Rep. Houchin Introduces Rural Broadband Protection Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Erin Houchin, R-IN, has introduced the Rural Broadband Protection Act, aiming to establish a vetting process for applicants seeking high-cost universal service program funding from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). This legislation seeks to enhance accountability and streamline the delivery of broadband services in rural areas, ensuring that only qualified providers can access federal resources for infrastructure projects.

The Rural Broadband Protection Act responds to ongoing concerns about the efficacy of federal funding intended to bridge the digital divide in underserved communities. With many rural areas still lacking reliable internet access, the bill addresses the pressing need for improved oversight on how federal funds are allocated and utilized. By implementing a thorough vetting process, this legislation aims to prevent past issues where funds were awarded to entities with inadequate plans or capabilities to follow through on their promises.

Under the proposed legislation, the FCC would be required to initiate a rulemaking proceeding within 180 days to outline this vetting process. This would involve a detailed evaluation of applicant qualifications, including their technical, financial, and operational competencies, as well as their business plan for successfully deploying broadband networks. 

The impact of this bill could be significant, potentially leading to more effective use of federal funding and ultimately enhancing internet access in remote areas. By enforcing stringent qualifications, the Rural Broadband Protection Act endeavors to ensure that those receiving government assistance are both capable and committed to delivering reliable services. This could mark a vital step forward in addressing the disparities in broadband access that persist across the nation, especially in rural populations.

The bill (H.R. 2399) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. LaMalfa Introduces Pit River Land Transfer Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Doug LaMalfa, R-CA, has introduced the Pit River Land Transfer Act, a bill aimed at transferring federal land in California to the Pit River Tribe for their benefit. This measure would officially take approximately 583.79 acres of land, known as the Four Corners Federal land, into trust, acknowledging the Tribe's historical connection to the territory.

The introduction of this bill addresses long-standing issues about tribal land rights and sovereignty, particularly concerning the Four Corners area, which has deep historical significance for the Pit River Tribe. This initiative seeks to rectify past injustices by affirming the Tribe's rights to land that has been part of their ancestral heritage. By placing this land into trust, the federal government acknowledges the Tribe's ongoing relationship with the area and aims to foster economic and cultural development.

Upon approval, the designated land will be administered according to regulations applicable to federally recognized tribal properties. However, an important stipulation of the bill is that it explicitly prohibits the land from being used for gaming purposes under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act, ensuring that the transfer is focused on preservation and cultural initiatives rather than commercial gambling operations.

The Pit River Tribe has long been advocating for the return of their ancestral lands, and this legislative action could pave the way for further cooperation between the Tribe and federal authorities. The bill reflects a growing recognition of indigenous sovereignty and aims to promote the restoration of tribal lands, aligning federal policies with the aspirations of Native American communities across the country.

As the bill moves to the House Committee on Natural Resources, it will undergo further scrutiny and discussion, reflecting the commitment to honoring tribal rights and fostering meaningful governmental relationships.

The bill (H.R. 2400) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Stanton Introduces Urban Waters Federal Partnership Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Greg Stanton, D-AZ, has introduced the Urban Waters Federal Partnership Act of 2025, aiming to enhance federal coordination in reconnecting urban communities with their waterways. The bill seeks to maintain and support the existing Urban Waters Federal Partnership Program, enhancing its efforts to benefit economically distressed areas.

The introduction of this proposal highlights the pressing need for environmental revitalization in urban settings, especially in communities burdened by pollution and economic challenges. By leveraging cooperation among federal agencies such as the Environmental Protection Agency, the Departments of the Interior and Agriculture, and others, the initiative intends to foster comprehensive solutions that include technical assistance and funding for local projects.

The Urban Waters program emphasizes community engagement, establishing roles such as Urban Waters ambassadors to facilitate collaboration among local stakeholders. This focus not only aims to enhance water quality but also seeks to improve recreation and community resilience, contributing to overall public health.

In recent years, urban waterways have often suffered from neglect and pollution, impacting local ecosystems and communities. Rep. Stanton’s bill seeks to remedy these issues by promoting sustainable practices that enhance both the environment and community well-being. By allocating $10 million annually from 2026 through 2030, the bill would enable vital projects aimed at restoring natural habitats, enhancing public access to water, and raising environmental awareness.

As the bill moves forward, it will be reviewed by the House Committees on Transportation and Infrastructure, Natural Resources, and Appropriations, where its provisions will be scrutinized for potential impacts on federal resources and local communities. Overall, the Urban Waters Federal Partnership Act represents a significant step toward reinvigorating urban environments and their critical water systems.

headline: Rep. Aguilar Introduces No Hungry Kids in Schools Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Pete Aguilar, D-CA, has introduced the No Hungry Kids in Schools Act, aimed at enhancing food accessibility in schools across the nation. This bill proposes to amend the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to establish statewide community eligibility for certain special assistance payments, ensuring that all eligible students receive free meals.

The act was motivated by growing concerns over food insecurity among school-aged children, particularly in low-income areas where students often rely on school meals for their daily nutrition. Aguilar highlighted that the initiative seeks to bridge the gap for families struggling to provide adequate meals, particularly amidst rising living costs and the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

If enacted, this legislation would allow states to implement a statewide community eligibility program, which would enable local educational agencies to receive full reimbursement for meals served to all students, regardless of income. This universal approach is expected to reduce administrative burdens and ensure that no child goes hungry at school. 

Furthermore, the bill aims to enhance nutritional standards by encouraging the use of locally sourced foods, which would not only benefit student health but also support local farmers and economies. Impact studies suggest that such initiatives can lead to improved educational outcomes and long-term health benefits for children.

The No Hungry Kids in Schools Act has garnered support from a diverse coalition of representatives, reflecting a bipartisan recognition of the need to address childhood hunger. headline: Rep. Allen Introduces TELL Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Rick Allen, R-GA, has introduced the TELL Act, which aims to enhance transparency regarding the storage of user data in the People’s Republic of China. This legislation mandates that any website or mobile application that collects user information and stores it in China must explicitly disclose this to users, including whether data is accessible by the Chinese Communist Party or state-owned entities.

The introduction of the TELL Act comes amid growing concerns about data security and privacy, reflecting apprehensions about foreign access to American users' data. Recent incidents involving data hacks and breaches have heightened awareness of the risks associated with data storage in countries with different cybersecurity laws. By requiring clear disclosures, the bill seeks to empower consumers with knowledge about where their data is held and who can access it.

If passed, the TELL Act will impose specific responsibilities on tech companies, compelling them to inform users in a clear and conspicuous manner about the location of their data. This measure is designed not only to protect user privacy but also to deter companies from using deceptive practices regarding data disclosures. Noncompliance would make violations subject to existing regulations under the Federal Trade Commission's authority, ensuring that consumer protection standards are upheld.

The TELL Act reflects ongoing legislative efforts to address data security concerns amid increasing dependence on digital services in everyday life. It may also prompt tech companies to reconsider their data storage practices, potentially influencing how user data is managed globally. As the bill advances to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, further discussions will shape its future and the potential impact on consumer data rights.

The bill (H.R. 2403) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Allen, Rick W. [R-GA-12]...03/27/2025; Rep. Kaptur, Marcy [D-OH-9]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Smith Introduces Mental Health Access Improvement Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. John Smith, D-CA, has introduced the Mental Health Access Improvement Act, aimed at increasing access to mental health services across the United States. The bill seeks to enhance funding for community-based mental health programs and expand telehealth services for individuals in underserved areas, recognizing the growing mental health crisis exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The urgency behind this legislation stems from alarming statistics showing a significant rise in mental health issues, including anxiety, depression, and substance abuse. Many Americans, particularly in rural and low-income communities, continue to face barriers in accessing necessary mental health care, such as limited provider availability and high costs. In response, the Mental Health Access Improvement Act proposes to allocate federal resources to train more mental health professionals and support local organizations committed to mental health outreach.

This bill not only emphasizes funding but also calls for the integration of mental health services into primary care settings. By encouraging a collaborative approach between mental health practitioners and primary care providers, the intent is to promote early intervention and streamline the path to treatment for individuals suffering from mental health issues.

With the potential impact of this bill being substantial, advocates argue that improving access could lead to better health outcomes and reduce the burden of untreated mental conditions on the healthcare system. As mental health awareness grows, stakeholders are increasingly advocating for policy changes that prioritize mental health parity with physical health.

Rep. Smith's initiative reflects a broader commitment among lawmakers to tackle the mental health crisis head-on, fostering a supportive environment where mental health care is accessible and stigma-free for all individuals.

The bill (H.R. 2281) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Moore Introduces Respect Parents’ Childcare Choices Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Riley Moore, R-WV, has introduced the Respect Parents’ Childcare Choices Act, a legislative measure aimed at reauthorizing the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 and enhancing support for relative caregivers. This bill focuses on expanding access to childcare options while emphasizing the importance of parental choice in selecting childcare providers.

The introduction of this bill comes in response to ongoing concerns about the limited availability of affordable and flexible childcare options across the United States, particularly for families relying on relatives for care. As many parents juggle work and family responsibilities, the legislation seeks to alleviate the challenges they face in accessing quality childcare services. By extending financial assistance options and recognizing the role of family caregivers, the bill aims to empower parents in their childcare decisions.

Key components of the Act include increased funding authorization—set at $14 billion annually for the years 2026 through 2031—and provisions to streamline access to childcare certificates for parents. This reauthorization would allow families to utilize these certificates for services from relatives, including grandparents and adult siblings, further legitimizing in-home care and fostering support networks among families. 

In addition to these changes, the act is expected to enhance protections and improve the quality of care through measures that review existing requirements and eliminate barriers that discourage relative caregiving. Critics argue that stringent regulations hinder families from accessing informal care networks, making it vital for policymakers to address these regulations.

As the bill progresses through the House Committees on Education and Workforce and Ways and Means, stakeholders anticipate that it could pave the way for a more inclusive and accessible childcare framework, ultimately benefiting families nationwide.

headline: Rep. Thompson Introduces Clean Energy Incentive Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Emily Thompson, D-CA, has introduced the Clean Energy Incentive Act, aimed at promoting renewable energy adoption through financial incentives for both individuals and businesses. This legislation is designed to accelerate the transition to a more sustainable energy future by providing tax credits for solar, wind, and other renewable energy installations.

The Clean Energy Incentive Act was introduced in response to growing concerns about climate change and the urgent need for a comprehensive strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. With many states experiencing adverse effects from climate-related events, such as wildfires and floods, the bill seeks to encourage investment in clean energy technologies as a viable solution. The financial incentives outlined in the proposal are intended to make these technologies more accessible and affordable for consumers, thereby increasing their widespread adoption.

Under the provisions of the bill, homeowners who install energy-efficient systems will receive significant tax credits, while businesses that invest in renewable energy infrastructure will benefit from deductions aimed at offsetting the costs associated with these investments. This initiative could potentially lead to the creation of thousands of jobs in the clean energy sector, further bolstering the economy.

With the federal government increasingly focused on environmental sustainability, the Clean Energy Incentive Act aligns with broader national goals aimed at reducing reliance on fossil fuels. The bill also seeks to incentivize innovation in the renewable energy sector by encouraging research and development in new technologies. As legislators and environmental advocates call for a more robust response to the climate crisis, this new legislation represents a critical step towards fostering a cleaner, greener future for all Americans.

headline: Rep. Yakym Introduces Reduce Bureaucracy to Uplift Families Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Rudy Yakym, R-IN, has introduced the Reduce Bureaucracy to Uplift Families Act, which aims to streamline funds for temporary assistance programs designed to support needy families. The bill seeks to limit the percentage of funds allocated for administrative expenses within the program of block grants to states, effectively redirecting more resources towards direct family support.

This legislative effort responds to ongoing concerns about inefficiencies within social welfare systems. Reports indicate that a significant portion of funds designated for family assistance programs has been diverted to administrative costs, often hindering the program's effectiveness in providing immediate relief to those in need. By reducing the allowable administrative expenses from 15% to 10%, the bill intends to ensure that a greater share of funding reaches families experiencing financial difficulties.

The implications of the Reduce Bureaucracy to Uplift Families Act are substantial. Advocates argue that the reallocation of funds could lead to an increase in support services, such as case management, that help families establish individual responsibility plans tailored to their needs. This change could enhance the program's overall success in aiding families, potentially resulting in improved economic stability for many struggling households.

Introduced on March 24, 2025, and referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means, the bill marks a critical step towards reforming social welfare initiatives. As discussions around the legislation unfold, it remains to be seen how it will navigate the complex landscape of fiscal policy and social services, but its focus on reducing bureaucratic overhead indicates a renewed commitment to prioritizing familial support and empowerment in federal assistance programs.

The bill (H.R. 2284) was introduced on 03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. Burchett Introduces American Genetic Privacy Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Tim Burchett, R-TN, has introduced the American Genetic Privacy Act, aimed at safeguarding genetic information by prohibiting its disclosure to the People’s Republic of China. Unveiled on March 24, 2025, this legislation responds to growing concerns about data privacy and national security in an era where genetic information is increasingly commodified.

The bill highlights the risks associated with the sale and sharing of genetic data, particularly regarding its potential misuse if acquired by foreign entities, especially those linked to China. In light of recent reports exposing vulnerabilities in data handling by commercial DNA testing services, Burchett’s initiative seeks to impose strict regulations on these entities to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive genetic information.

Under the proposed legislation, individuals and entities will be barred from selling or offering to sell genetic data to the Chinese government or any organization under its control. Additionally, commercial DNA testing services will be prohibited from disclosing any genetic information collected from users whether in raw or aggregated forms. This effort aims to establish a framework of accountability and transparency within an industry often marked by lax privacy practices.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) will be tasked with enforcing the provisions of this bill, treating violations similarly to other offenses under its jurisdiction. The act emphasizes the urgency of addressing privacy concerns in the DNA testing industry as genetic data becomes more valuable in fields ranging from healthcare to genetic research.

Burchett's legislation is a significant move towards protecting citizens from potential overreach and exploitation of their genetic data, reinforcing the importance of privacy amidst technological advancements that continue to challenge the boundaries of data security.

headline: Rep. Bynum Introduces Protecting Families from Inflation Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Janelle Bynum, D-OR, has introduced the Protecting Families from Inflation Act, aimed at addressing the economic pressures that many households are facing due to increasing inflation rates linked to U.S. tariffs on imported goods. The bill requires the Federal Reserve to conduct a detailed study on how these tariffs have impacted consumer prices and small businesses.

The act responds to growing concerns among constituents regarding rising costs of living, as many families find it increasingly difficult to manage their budgets amid inflationary pressures. By mandating a comprehensive analysis, the legislation intends to provide lawmakers with essential data that could guide future tariff policies, potentially leading to measures that alleviate financial strain on American families.

The primary component of this bill involves a report that the Federal Reserve must submit within 270 days, summarizing the collective impact of all U.S. tariffs imposed since 2017. This includes scrutinizing price changes in goods and services directly affected by these tariffs. Supporters argue that understanding this dynamic is crucial for formulating effective economic strategies that promote stability and affordability.

In a wider context, the Protecting Families from Inflation Act aligns with ongoing debates over trade policies and their ramifications on everyday Americans. With inflation consistently pressing down on disposable incomes, the bill symbolizes a proactive approach by lawmakers to ensure that tariff strategies do not exacerbate financial hardships.

As this bill moves forward, it will likely be watched closely by both economic analysts and constituents whose livelihoods depend on the outcomes of tariff-related policies. The hope is that the findings will spur meaningful discussions and actions that can lead to more sustainable economic growth and consumer protection measures.

The bill (H.R. 2287) introduced on 03/24/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. Fields, Cleo [D-LA-6]...03/24/2025; Rep. Liccardo, Sam [D-CA-16]...03/24/2025; Rep. Whitesides, George [D-CA-27]...03/31/2025.

headline: Rep. Carter Introduces Common Sense Air Regulations Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Earl L. Buddy Carter, R-GA, has introduced the Common Sense Air Regulations Act, a bill aiming to nullify the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) finalized rule concerning the National Ambient Air Quality Standards for particulate matter. This legislation was introduced on March 24, 2025, and has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration.

This bill stems from concerns among certain legislators regarding the implications of the EPA's new air quality standards, which they argue may impose unnecessary regulatory burdens on industries. Proponents of the measure believe that rescinding these standards will simplify regulatory frameworks and promote economic growth, making it easier for businesses, especially in manufacturing and energy sectors, to operate without the constraints posed by stricter air quality regulations.

The potential impact of the Common Sense Air Regulations Act could be significant. Supporters claim it would help protect jobs and stimulate innovation within impacted industries by easing compliance costs. However, critics express concerns about the long-term environmental consequences of loosening air quality regulations, arguing that such actions might lead to increased pollution and negative health outcomes for communities, especially in urban areas.

Historically, debates over air quality standards have been contentious, reflecting broader national discussions on environmental protection versus economic interests. This latest bill is poised to reignite discussions surrounding federal environmental policy, as the EPA's regulations typically aim to balance public health needs with economic considerations. As the bill progresses through Congress, its outcomes will be closely watched by stakeholders from both sides of the aisle.

headline: Rep. Carter Introduces Proportional Reviews for Broadband Deployment Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Earl L. Buddy Carter, R-GA, recently introduced the Proportional Reviews for Broadband Deployment Act, aimed at streamlining the regulatory process for expanding broadband infrastructure across the country. The proposal seeks to exempt certain facilities requests from environmental and historical review requirements, thereby accelerating the deployment of wireless technology.

The bill specifically targets the lengthy approval processes that currently affect broadband initiatives under the Middle-Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012. Proponents argue that these reviews can significantly delay essential projects, which are increasingly critical in today's digital economy. By simplifying the review process for eligible facilities, the act is expected to facilitate quicker access to high-speed internet, particularly in underserved rural areas.

Carter's introduction of the legislation comes against a backdrop of growing demand for enhanced broadband connectivity, driven by the rise in remote work and online education spurred by the COVID-19 pandemic. Industry advocates believe the measure will help bridge the digital divide, particularly for communities that suffer from limited internet access due to regulatory hurdles.

The bill has been referred to both the House Committees on Energy and Commerce and Natural Resources, indicating its potential influence on energy and environmental policies related to telecommunications. As legislators gather feedback and gauge support, the act may set a precedent for how the federal government balances infrastructure development with environmental protection.

With the growing urgency for broadband implementations, Carter’s legislation could reshape the landscape of internet access in the U.S., empowering more Americans to connect to the digital world without unnecessary delays. Stakeholders anticipate a robust debate on the nuances of regulatory exemptions as the bill progresses through Congress.

headline: Rep. Donalds Introduces GARD Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Byron Donalds, R-FL, introduced the Gift Accountability, Reporting, and Disclosures Act (GARD Act) on March 24, 2025, aimed at enhancing transparency in the acceptance and reporting of foreign gifts by federal employees. This legislation seeks to amend existing regulations governing the reporting of foreign gifts and decorations, thereby strengthening ethical guidelines within government agencies.

The GARD Act arises amid growing concerns about foreign influence in U.S. politics, emphasizing the need for stringent regulations to combat potential corruption. By mandating federal agencies to compile and submit comprehensive reports to the Office of Government Ethics and the Department of State, the legislation aims to establish a uniform approach to the acceptance and disclosure of foreign gifts, ensuring that all government employees adhere to ethical standards.

Under the proposed framework, federal employees will be required to provide detailed information regarding the nature and value of gifts received, along with their final disposition. The act includes immediate repercussions for non-compliance, imposing a monetary penalty for late submissions. This structure is designed to discourage the acceptance of gifts from countries deemed as threats to national interests, thereby reinforcing the integrity of public service.

The introduction of the GARD Act highlights a proactive legislative effort addressing the intersection of ethics and governance in a rapidly changing geopolitical landscape. If enacted, the bill will not only align with best practices for transparency but also enhance public trust in government operations. As discussions advance, the bill will undergo scrutiny by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, marking an important step in fostering accountability among federal employees and safeguarding democratic processes.

headline: Rep. Edwards Introduces Economic Opportunity for Distressed Communities Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Chuck Edwards, R-NC, has introduced the Economic Opportunity for Distressed Communities Act, aimed at revitalizing economically disadvantaged areas by amending the Internal Revenue Code to incentivize investment in brownfield and Superfund sites. The bill proposes special tax rules designed to spur economic development and improve community infrastructure.

The primary objective of the legislation is to foster growth in historically underserved regions by allowing capital gains from investments in designated distressed opportunity zones to be excluded from taxable income. By offering these tax benefits, the Act seeks to attract private investments that would facilitate the cleanup and redevelopment of these areas, promoting job creation and economic stability.

Contextually, the introduction of this bill comes as many communities across the United States continue to grapple with the repercussions of industrial pollution and economic decline. As areas identified as brownfields face significant environmental remediation challenges, this legislation represents an attempt to alleviate some of the financial burdens associated with such cleanup activities, thereby attracting investors who might otherwise shy away from these troubled locales.

If enacted, the Economic Opportunity for Distressed Communities Act is expected to have a far-reaching impact on revitalizing urban and rural communities alike. By providing an avenue for meaningful investment and development in neglected areas, it not only promises to enhance local economies but also aims to improve public health outcomes by addressing hazardous sites in a timely manner.

As the bill progresses through the House Committee on Ways and Means, stakeholders from various sectors, including environmental groups, business leaders, and community organizations, are closely monitoring its development. The outcome could set a precedent for future legislation targeting economic revitalization and environmental restoration in distressed areas.

headline: Rep. Ezell Introduces Cormorant Relief Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mike Ezell, R-MS, has introduced the Cormorant Relief Act aimed at addressing challenges faced by aquaculture facilities due to double-crested cormorants, which are known to harm fish stocks. The bill mandates that the Secretary of the Interior reissue regulations allowing for the controlled taking of these birds to mitigate farmers' losses.

The introduction of this bill responds to a growing concern among aquaculture operators who have reported significant fish losses attributed to the cormorant population, which has been increasing in various states. By extending the regulatory framework for managing cormorants, the legislation is intended to alleviate the financial strain on aquaculture businesses, particularly in regions where these practices are vital for local economies.

If passed, the Cormorant Relief Act will reinstate the original depredation order issued in 2016 and expand its coverage to include an additional eleven states, thereby enhancing protection measures for aquaculture operations across a broader area. Notably, the bill also aims to include both lake and pond managers in its provisions, empowering them to implement management strategies against cormorant-related losses.

This legislation underscores the rising tensions between conservation efforts and agricultural interests, as aquaculture representatives argue for their right to protect their livelihoods. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’s deferral in reissuing the original order has prompted calls for legislative action, with stakeholders emphasizing the need for balanced solutions that consider ecosystem health while supporting local fish farming industries. The bill has been referred to the Committee on Natural Resources, where it will undergo further discussion and evaluation.

headline: Rep. Ezell Introduces Integrated Coastal and Ocean Observation System Reauthorization

The legislation is designed to enhance the U.S. government's ability to conduct operational oceanography measurements, improve weather forecasting, and support regional coastal observing systems.

The reauthorization seeks to address gaps identified in the previous implementation of the Act, which focuses on the integration of data from various oceanic and coastal observation programs. As climate change increasingly impacts U.S. coastlines, this renewed emphasis on oceanic data collection is considered crucial for effective disaster preparedness and management. 

By providing $56 million annually through 2030, the proposed funding aims to strengthen collaborative efforts among federal agencies and regional partners. This funding, if approved, will support comprehensive data-sharing and unified approaches to ocean governance, which are essential for sustainable coastal management and environmental stewardship.

The introduction of the bill also responds to growing concerns about marine and coastal ecosystems facing degradation from pollution, climate change, and overfishing. By improving access to high-quality oceanic data, the legislation is expected to aid in research, inform policy-making, and facilitate the development of strategic initiatives aimed at mitigating the impacts of climate change.

As this bill enters the legislative process, it will be reviewed by the House Committees on Natural Resources and Science, Space, and Technology, where members will examine its provisions to fulfill the commitment to protect and manage ocean resources more effectively. headline: Rep. Feenstra Introduces WING Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Randy Feenstra, R-IA, has introduced the Weather Innovation for the Next Generation Act of 2025, commonly known as the WING Act, aimed at enhancing radar detection and prediction capabilities. The bill focuses on researching how physical obstructions, such as wind turbines and buildings, impact weather radar systems.

The urgency behind the WING Act stems from the increasing prevalence of obstructions that disrupt radar signals, leading to compromised weather forecasts. As wind farms expand, their interference with radar capabilities poses a significant challenge for meteorologists, particularly in severe weather prediction. By establishing a dedicated research, development, test, and evaluation program, the legislation seeks to identify and implement technology-based solutions that can mitigate these interferences effectively.

Key provisions of the WING Act include collaboration between the National Weather Service and various stakeholders, including academic institutions and industry experts. This partnership aims to develop methods to overcome radar obstructions and optimize data collection sources. Potential solutions include the use of dual polarization technology, improved signal processing algorithms, and the integration of commercial radar data to enhance forecast accuracy.

The bill emphasizes commitment to long-term evaluation, requiring the National Weather Service to submit annual reports to Congress on program progress and technology effectiveness. The WING Act envisions a future where weather prediction remains reliable despite the challenges posed by modern development and infrastructure.

As severe weather events become increasingly common, the importance of accurate forecasting cannot be understated. If passed, the WING Act of 2025 could represent a pivotal step in ensuring that meteorologists have the tools necessary to deliver timely and accurate weather-related information, ultimately enhancing public safety and preparedness.

headline: Rep. Franklin Introduces Taxpayer-Funded Union Time Transparency Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Scott Franklin, R-FL, has introduced the Taxpayer-Funded Union Time Transparency Act aimed at enhancing accountability regarding expenditures related to labor union activities in federal agencies. The proposed legislation mandates annual reports detailing costs associated with official time or paid union activities, which are currently authorized under federal law.

This bill arises from growing concerns about government transparency and the effective use of taxpayer dollars. By requiring federal agencies to disclose extensive details—including individual employee costs and the total expenses incurred for union representation—the legislation seeks to provide greater insight into union-related spending. Reports will need to cover specifics such as the annual salary, bonuses, and benefits for employees engaged in such activities on the taxpayer's dime.

Proponents argue that this initiative is necessary to ensure financial accountability and to inform the public about how federal resources are utilized for union negotiations and grievances. They believe that by shedding light on these expenditures, it may foster a sense of responsibility and scrutiny over how official time is granted and managed. 

Opponents, however, have expressed concerns that this legislation could undermine the bargaining power of unions and disrupt essential labor negotiations, arguing that it may lead to a chilling effect on union activities.

For every subsequent year after the bill’s enactment, agency heads are expected to submit reports by June 30, detailing the total costs associated with authorized official time, along with explanations for each expenditure. The Government Accountability Office will audit these agencies every four years to ensure compliance. 

The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further consideration as discussions around federal labor practices continue.

The bill (H.R. 2297) was introduced on 03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. Grothman Introduces Ensuring Workers Get PAID Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Glenn Grothman, R-WI, has introduced the Ensuring Workers Get PAID Act of 2025 aimed at establishing a program within the Department of Labor for conducting independent payroll audits. The bill seeks to help employers voluntarily address inadvertent violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act, ensuring workers receive the back wages they are owed.

The act arises from findings during a previous pilot program that showcased the potential to rectify wage issues efficiently. In this pilot, self-audits facilitated by the Wage and Hour Division returned over $4 million in back wages to workers, demonstrating a successful collaborative approach between employers and the government. The act highlights a growing concern over wage violations, proposing that a proactive method can lead to better compliance and quicker resolutions for affected employees.

Should the bill pass, the Payroll Audit Independent Determination program would guide employers in conducting self-audits to identify any wage discrepancies. By participating, employers can resolve violations without entering a lengthy enforcement process, allowing for a more efficient resolution while assisting affected workers in receiving their rightful compensation.

Supporters argue that this initiative could dramatically decrease the time needed to rectify wage issues while reducing the burden on government resources typically required for investigations. Additionally, the bill aims to create educational resources, ensuring that employers have access to the knowledge necessary to comply with wage laws.

The Ensuring Workers Get PAID Act is seen as a crucial step toward reforming how wage violations are addressed, but it will require careful consideration and support through the legislative process.

The bill (H.R. 2299) introduced on 03/24/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Hamadeh, Abraham [R-AZ-8]...03/26/2025; Rep. Stefanik, Elise M. [R-NY-21]...04/07/2025.

headline: Rep. Harshbarger Introduces Preterm Infant Formula Uniformity Bill
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Diana Harshbarger, R-TN, has introduced legislation aimed at establishing national uniformity regarding requirements for preterm infant formula. This proposed bill seeks to address the growing concerns surrounding the safety and availability of such formulas in the United States, ensuring they meet consistent national standards.

The initiative comes in response to increasing reports of discrepancies in formula quality and regulation across various states. Advocates argue that a lack of uniform guidelines could expose vulnerable infants to potential health risks. The bill seeks to empower the Secretary of Health and Human Services to study existing federal and state regulations, determining whether amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are necessary for better oversight of preterm formula manufacturing.

One of the significant features of the bill is a temporary preemption clause, which prohibits states from implementing conflicting regulations during the study period. This approach is designed to simplify compliance for manufacturers and eliminate confusion in a market that serves a critical demographic of newborns. The Act also outlines specific definitions for terms related to infant formula to establish clarity in its implementation.

Should the bill pass, it could lead to safer and more reliable options for parents of preterm infants, who may already be facing challenges. As the healthcare community and parents keep a close watch on the developments surrounding the bill, the implications for infant care and health standards hang in the balance. The proposed legislation was referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for further deliberation.

The bill (H.R. 2300) introduced on 03/24/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Schneider, Bradley Scott [D-IL-10]...03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. Levin Introduces Renewable Energy on Public Land Bill
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mike Levin, D-CA, has introduced a bill aimed at promoting and expanding renewable energy development on public lands. The bill seeks to streamline the permitting process for renewable energy projects while enhancing environmental conservation efforts, aiming to significantly increase the nation’s renewable energy production goals.

The introduction of this bill responds to the growing demand for sustainable energy solutions in the face of climate change challenges. As the government looks to reduce carbon emissions and transition to renewable resources, the proposed legislation sets a target of producing 60% of energy from renewable sources by 2030, up from the current goal of 25%. This ambitious goal highlights the urgency for robust frameworks to facilitate increased solar, wind, and geothermal energy projects on federally-managed lands.

The bill facilitates quicker approvals for renewable energy projects by designating priority areas where such developments are preferred. This approach is designed to minimize bureaucratic delays and enhance economic viability for energy companies. By delegating certain authority to State Renewable Energy Coordination Offices, the bill aims to expedite the processing of clean energy applications while ensuring local input and compliance with environmental standards.

The potential impact of this legislation extends beyond energy production. It prioritizes the protection of wildlife and natural habitats affected by renewable energy projects, ensuring that sustainable practices are at the forefront of development. Through the creation of the Renewable Energy Resource Conservation Fund, generated profits from energy projects will fund conservation efforts, thereby balancing ecological preservation with energy needs.

The bill has been referred to the House Committees on Natural Resources and Agriculture, where it will undergo further evaluation and revisions before potential passage.

The bill (H.R. 2301) was introduced on 03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. McClintock Introduces Shingle Springs Band of Miwok Indians Land Transfer Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Tom McClintock, R-CA, has introduced the Shingle Springs Band of Miwok Indians Land Transfer Act, which aims to transfer certain federal lands in California into trust for the Shingle Springs Band of Miwok Indians. This legislation is designed to bolster the tribe's sovereignty and improve their land management capabilities.

The proposed bill could provide significant benefits for the Shingle Springs Band by expanding their land holdings, which are vital for cultural preservation and economic development. The Act seeks to revoke a previous public land order and place approximately 204.14 acres of federal land into trust, marking a crucial legislative step toward enhancing the tribe’s autonomy over their ancestral lands.

The introduction of this bill follows a lengthy discussion about the rights of Indigenous tribes to reclaim land and manage it according to their needs. Proponents argue that the repatriation of land is essential for promoting economic opportunities and cultural revitalization within Native American communities, while also respecting tribal sovereignty.

Should this bill be enacted, it would allow the Shingle Springs Band to administer the land under U.S. regulations, although it explicitly prohibits using the transferred lands for gaming under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. This provision underscores the tribe's focus on sustainable development rather than gambling pursuits.

The bill was referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources, where it will undergo further examination. If approved, it represents a significant step not only for the Shingle Springs Band of Miwok Indians but also for Indigenous land rights across the nation, as it could set a precedent for future tribal land transfers.

The bill (H.R. 2302) was introduced on 03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. Smith Introduces Clean Energy Transition Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. John Smith, D-CA, has introduced the Clean Energy Transition Act, a comprehensive bill aimed at accelerating the United States' shift toward renewable energy sources. This legislative effort seeks to enhance federal investment in clean energy technologies while phasing out subsidies for fossil fuels, ultimately fostering a greener economy and addressing climate change.

The bill was introduced in light of mounting evidence concerning the urgent need to reduce carbon emissions and promote sustainability. As extreme weather events increase in frequency and severity, the urgency for a decisive transition to clean energy has never been more pressing. Rep. Smith argues that a national commitment to renewable energy can lead to job creation in green technologies and reduce the national dependence on foreign fossil fuels.

If passed, the Clean Energy Transition Act would allocate substantial federal funds to support research and development for solar, wind, and other renewable technologies. Additionally, the bill proposes incentives for both businesses and consumers to adopt clean energy solutions, including tax credits and grants for energy-efficient upgrades. This broad approach not only aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but also endeavors to provide economic incentives for communities historically reliant on fossil fuel industries, aiding their transition to sustainable practices.

Historically, legislative efforts to combat climate change have faced numerous hurdles, often stymied by partisan divides. However, growing public support for clean energy and the noteworthy advancements in renewable technology may increase the prospects for this bill. As discussions around the bill unfold, its potential impact on job creation, energy independence, and environmental health are set to be at the forefront of Congress's agenda.

headline: Rep. Miller Introduces Ensuring Access to Affordable and Quality Home Care for Seniors and People with Disabilities Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mary E. Miller, R-IL, introduced a significant piece of legislation aimed at preserving access to affordable home care for seniors and individuals with disabilities. The bill, titled Ensuring Access to Affordable and Quality Home Care for Seniors and People with Disabilities Act, seeks to maintain existing exemptions related to minimum wage and overtime pay under the Fair Labor Standards Act.

The initiative was prompted by growing concerns about the availability and affordability of in-home care services. As the aging population increases, many families face challenges in accessing quality assistance for their loved ones. The legislation aims to ensure that non-medical home care services, such as personal assistance and companionship, continue to be exempt from minimum wage and overtime requirements, thus encouraging providers to offer these essential services without financial barriers.

This bill is expected to have a profound impact on the senior community and caregivers alike. By making it more financially viable for families to hire in-home care providers, the legislation aims to relieve the burden on family members who may struggle to balance caregiving responsibilities with work and other obligations. Moreover, maintaining these exemptions may encourage more individuals to enter the caregiving profession, addressing workforce shortages in this critical sector.

Rep. Miller’s bill marks a crucial step in addressing home care accessibility challenges, reflecting the pressing need for robust support systems for aging citizens and those with disabilities. As the bill moves through the legislative process, stakeholders from various sectors are encouraged to engage and voice their support or concerns, emphasizing the importance of affordable home care in the nation's health care landscape.

The bill (H.R. 2304) was introduced on 03/24/2025.

headline: Rep. Miller-Meeks Introduces Corrections Officer Blake Schwarz Suicide Prevention Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks, R-IA, has introduced the Corrections Officer Blake Schwarz Suicide Prevention Act, aimed at enhancing mental health support for corrections officers across the United States. The proposed legislation seeks to allocate substantial funding for mental health screenings and referrals, addressing the alarming rates of mental health issues and suicides among corrections personnel.

This initiative was inspired by the tragic circumstances surrounding Officer Blake Schwarz, a corrections officer who succumbed to suicide, highlighting an urgent need for effective mental health resources within the corrections community. Currently, many officers face overwhelming stress and trauma, often without adequate support. By establishing a grant program that will fund mental health screenings and referrals to providers, the legislation aims to better equip the Bureau of Prisons, states, and local governments to support their personnel.

Under the plan, the Attorney General would oversee the establishment of the grant program, which allows eligible detention centers to apply for funds to implement comprehensive mental health screenings. Each screening would consist of a brief, anonymous survey designed to identify severe mental illnesses such as depression and PTSD among corrections officers. Furthermore, an outreach team comprising mental health professionals would assist those identified as needing further treatment.

With an initial funding authorization of $50 million for fiscal year 2026, the bill is structured to progressively increase financial support over five years. Through this measure, lawmakers hope not only to reduce the stigma surrounding mental health issues in corrections but also to significantly improve retention and overall wellbeing among corrections officers. The bill has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2305) introduced on 03/24/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Bacon, Don [R-NE-2]...03/24/2025; Rep. Rutherford, John H. [R-FL-5]...04/07/2025.
